result.markdown:
--- title: Attributive marker author: Asya Alekseeva date: 'Last update: 2024-02-26' output: html_document: number_sections: true anchor_sections: true pandoc_args: --shift-heading-level-by=-1 --- Attributive marker can be either *-dɨ*, either *-d*. We asked nine contexts, six with the head ‘knife’: ‘(my) brother's knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘I slaughtered a sheep with (my) brother's knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in oblique case), ‘sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with a sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in oblique case), ‘my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in oblique case). And three contexts with the head ‘dog’: ‘lame dog’ (dependent adjective), ‘my dog’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive), ‘(my) brother's dog’ (dependent noun in attributive). The difference between the words ‘knife’ and ‘dog’ is that ‘knife’ is a noun of 4th gender class, and ‘dog’ — of 3rd gender class. These maps show the variation of attributive markers in these nine contexts. ## ‘brother’s knife’ ::: {.panel-tabset} ### Map ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
